_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: wet chlorine scrubber removed and replaced with a Denora dry chemical scrubber
_prev_prog_3.TR_OtherType: Formation of a Safety Committee, Review all elements of RMP with employees and revise as required.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: chlorinators, trolley and hoist, tank scales, vacuum regulator, chlorine filter.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary 
The Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule are targeted at highly hazardous chemicals that have the potential to cause a catastrophic incident. This Washington Department of Labor and Industries (WA L&I) standard and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) rule are required by the Clean Air Act Amendments and are outlined in Washington State Regulation WAC 296-67 and Federal Regulation 40 CFR Part 68, respectively.  This RMP/PSM was originally prepared by Lance Environmental Services, 17211 NE 95th Street, Redmond, Washington 98052.  It is intended to aid American Water Services CDM, as contract operator of Seattle Public Utilities (SPU)  Tolt Treatment Facility, in their efforts to prevent or mitigate episodic chemical releases that could lead to a catastrophe in the workplace and possibly to the surrounding community. This Program will ensure full compliance with Regulations WAC 296-67 and 40 CFR Part 68 and should serve to enhance SPUs and American Water Services CDMs relationship with our neighbors in Duvall and Carnation.
The major objective of the RMP/PSM for highly hazardous chemicals is to prevent unwanted releases of hazardous chemicals, especially into locations that could expose employees and others to serious hazards. An effective RMP/PSM plan requires a systematic approach to evaluating the whole process. Using this approach, the process design, process technology, worst-case scenario, alternate scenarios, operational and maintenance activities and procedures, non-routine activities and procedures, emergency preparedness plans and procedures, training programs, and other elements that impact the unit processes, were all considered in our evaluation.  The various lines of defense that were incorporated into design and operation of the Seattle Public Utilities Tolt Treatment Facility (Tolt) to prevent or mitigate the release of hazardous chemicals were re-evaluated, enhanced and are we

ll documented within the five-year accident history of the facility.  
Chemicals stored at the Tolt Treatment Facility that are targeted by the PSM and/or the RMP are chlorine, ozone, and propane. 
Chlorine - stored in quantities above the WAC 296-67 threshold limit of 1,500 lbs. - stored in quantities above the 40 CFR Part 68 threshold limit of 2,500 lbs.
Ozone - stored in quantities below the WAC 296-67 threshold limit of 100 pounds.
Propane - used solely for comfort heating.
Therefore, chlorine is the chemical addressed in this Process Safety Management & Risk Management Plan, as required by the WA L&I Process Safety Management Regulation WAC 296-67 and the EPA Risk Management Plan Regulation 40 CFR Part 68.  
The Tolt Water Treatment Facility will store up to 20 tons of chlorine gas in one-ton containers.  Containers will be stored in an enclosed building with a chlorine scrubber and gas containment provided by the building.  The facility is equipped with gas detectors that will activate the scrubber system in the event of a chlorine release.  The facility is staffed 24 hours a day by at least one licensed Water Treatment Operator.  During normal business hours there may be other employees, contractors, and/or consultants engaged in work at the facility.  The chlorine storage area at the facility is a secured zone and all access doors will be locked at all times unless authorized personnel are present.   American Water Services CDM and SPU are committed to protecting employees, the public, and the environment from the release of chlorine gas.
NOTE:  American Water Services-CDM, Inc. will no longer have responsibility for the operations and maintenance  SPUs Tolt Treatment Facility  when its services agreement  with SPU ends sometime between January 2025 and no later than February 2026.  SPU will take over the operations and maintenance responsibility for the facility and will have the responsibility for the Rick Management Plan and the Process Safety Management
